choices.answer: Breathing
Breathing and transporting oxygen around the body
Cells making useful molecules such as proteins
A chemical reaction where energy is released from glucose

questions.question: What are the reactants required for aerobic respiration?

choices.answer: Glucose and oxygen
Glucose and carbon dioxide
Glucose and water
Oxygen and water

questions.question: What are the products of aerobic respiration?

choices.answer: Carbon dioxide and sweat
Glucose and oxygen
Water and oxygen
Carbon dioxide and water

questions.question: Where do human cells get their glucose from?

choices.answer: Photosynthesis
Food, which is digested, and glucose passes into the blood
Glycogen stores inside the cell
Cells synthesise glucose from smaller sugar molecules

questions.question: Why do cells need to respire?

choices.answer: To keep nutrients coming into the cell
To keep warm
To synthesise large molecules such as proteins
To make carbon dioxide and water

questions.question: What changes occur in the body during exercise to increase respiration?

choices.answer: Heart rate and breathing rate increase; glycogen --> glucose
Heart rate and breathing rate increase; glucose --> glycogen
Heart rate increases but breathing rate decreases
You sweat to get rid of water which is a waste product

questions.question: Where do plants get the glucose for aerobic respiration from?

choices.answer: Roots take it up from the soil
Food
They synthesise glucose from smaller sugar molecules
Photosynthesis
Aerobic respiration
Anaerobic respiration

questions.question: What is the product of anaerobic respiration?

choices.answer: Carbon dioxide and water
Carbon dioxide and lactic acid
Lactic acid
Water
When you borrow oxygen and you have to repay it
The amount of oxygen needed to catch your breath
The amount of oxygen needed for aerobic respiration
The amount of oxygen needed to break down lactic acid

questions.question: How is lactic acid removed from cells?

choices.answer: It is transported out of the cell
It is reacted with oxygen which breaks it down
It is reacted with carbon dioxide to break it down
It is breathed out as a waste product
